questions.question: How do you multiply two matrices?
similar: What is the rule for multiplying matrices?
How to find C = A × B?
answers: To multiply two matrices A (m×n) and B (n×p), the result is a matrix C (m×p). Each element cᵢⱼ is the dot product of the i-th row of A and the j-th column of B.
Multiply rows of the first matrix by columns of the second and sum the products to get each element.

questions.question: What is Bayes' Theorem?
similar: How to update probability with Bayes?
answers: Bayes' Theorem: P(A|B) = [P(B|A) × P(A)] / P(B). It helps update probabilities based on new evidence.
It’s a way to revise existing probability estimates when new data is available.

questions.question: What is integration by parts?
answers: Formula: ∫u dv = uv - ∫v du. Choose u and dv wisely using the LIATE rule (Logarithmic, Inverse trig, Algebraic, Trig, Exponential).
Pick u as the function that becomes simpler when differentiated, and dv as the rest.

questions.question: How to solve a first order linear differential equation?
answers: General form: dy/dx + P(x)y = Q(x). Use integrating factor μ(x) = e^(∫P(x)dx) to solve.
Multiply through by the integrating factor, then integrate both sides.

questions.question: polar form of a complex number
answers: Any complex number z = x + iy can be written as r(cosθ + i sinθ), where r = |z| and θ = arg(z).
Polar form expresses a complex number in terms of magnitude and angle.

questions.question: What is the dot product of two vectors?
answers: Dot product of vectors A and B: A · B = |A||B|cosθ. It gives a scalar value representing projection.
Multiply corresponding components and sum them to get the dot product.

questions.question: What is the Euclidean Algorithm?
answers: To find GCD of a and b: repeatedly apply a = bq + r until r = 0. Last non-zero remainder is the GCD.
It’s an efficient way to compute the greatest common divisor using repeated division.

questions.question: How to prove by mathematical induction?
answers: Step 1: Prove base case. Step 2: Assume true for n = k. Step 3: Prove for n = k+1. If both hold, the statement is true for all n.
Show it works for the first case, then prove that if it works for one case, it works for the next.

questions.question: What is the graphical method in linear programming?
answers: Plot constraints as inequalities, identify feasible region, and evaluate objective function at corner points.
Graph the constraints, shade the feasible region, and check vertices for the optimal solution.

questions.question: my child has fever
answers: A mild fever can be the body fighting an infection. Keep your child hydrated, dress them lightly, and monitor their temperature.
If fever lasts more than 24 hours (under 2 years) or 48 hours (over 2 years), or is very high, please contact a pediatrician.
Seek urgent care if your child is lethargic, has trouble breathing, a stiff neck, seizures, or is under 3 months with any fever.

questions.question: my child has cough and cold
answers: Give warm fluids and ensure rest. A humidifier may ease breathing. Honey can help for children over 1 year (avoid in infants).
If cough lasts more than 2 weeks, has wheezing, fast breathing, or high fever, please see a pediatrician.
If your child is struggling to breathe, has bluish lips, or chest pulling in, seek urgent medical attention.

questions.question: my child is vomiting
answers: Offer small sips of oral rehydration solution frequently to prevent dehydration. Avoid solid foods until vomiting settles.
See a doctor if vomiting persists > 8–12 hours, there is blood or green bile, severe stomach pain, or signs of dehydration.
Go to urgent care if your child is very drowsy, has a stiff neck, severe headache, or cannot keep fluids down at all.

questions.question: my child has diarrhea
answers: Focus on hydration with oral rehydration solution. Continue regular feeding if possible. Avoid sugary drinks.
See a doctor if diarrhea lasts more than 2 days, there is blood/mucus in stool, fever, or signs of dehydration.
Urgent care is needed if your child is very sleepy, has sunken eyes, no tears, or pees very little.

questions.question: signs of dehydration in child
answers: Watch for dry mouth and lips, fewer wet diapers/urination, sunken eyes, no tears when crying, and unusual sleepiness or irritability.
Offer oral rehydration solution in small, frequent sips. If your child refuses to drink or worsens, see a doctor.
Seek urgent care if dehydration signs are severe or your child can’t keep fluids down.

questions.question: my child has a rash
answers: Many rashes are mild and viral. Track fever and other symptoms, and avoid scratching. Keep skin cool and clean.
See a doctor if the rash is painful, rapidly spreading, with high fever, or your child seems unwell.
Seek emergency care if the rash looks like bruises or purple spots that don’t fade under pressure, or if there is difficulty breathing.

questions.question: my child has ear pain
answers: Ear pain can follow a cold. Use warm compresses and age-appropriate pain relief if advised by your doctor.
See a pediatrician if pain is severe, lasts more than a day, there is fever, fluid from the ear, or hearing issues.
Keep the ear dry and avoid inserting anything into the ear canal.

questions.question: sore throat in child
answers: Offer warm fluids and rest. Throat pain often follows viral colds and may settle in a few days.
See a doctor if there is high fever, swollen glands, white patches in the throat, or symptoms persist.
Seek urgent care if your child drools, has difficulty breathing, or cannot swallow fluids.

questions.question: abdominal pain in child
answers: Mild tummy aches are common. Encourage rest, fluids, and track bowel movements and fever.
See a doctor if pain is severe, localized (especially right lower side), with vomiting, fever, or pain that wakes the child.
Urgent attention is needed for a hard, bloated belly, persistent vomiting, blood in stool, or the child is very unwell.

questions.question: my child is anxious
answers: Acknowledge their feelings and create a calm routine. Slow breaths: inhale 4, hold 4, exhale 6—practice together.
Offer reassurance and predictability. If anxiety interferes with daily life, consider counseling with a child therapist.
You’re not alone—early support helps. If panic symptoms occur frequently, seek professional guidance.

questions.question: panic attack help for child
answers: Stay close, speak softly, and guide slow breathing: in through the nose, long out-breaths. Reduce stimulation if possible.
Remind them the feeling will pass and they are safe. Afterward, discuss coping strategies and triggers with a professional.
If breathing is very difficult, fainting occurs, or chest pain is severe, seek urgent medical care.

questions.question: my child is being bullied
answers: Listen without judgment, validate their feelings, and document incidents. Your child’s safety and confidence come first.
Inform the school and work with trusted staff to create a plan. Teach assertive responses and safe help-seeking.
If there are injuries, severe distress, or threats, seek professional and school support urgently.

questions.question: my child can’t sleep well
answers: Keep a consistent bedtime routine, reduce screens 1–2 hours before bed, and keep the room dark and cool.
If sleep issues persist, snoring is loud, or there are breathing pauses, consult a pediatrician.
Gentle wind-down activities like reading and calm music can help signal sleep time.

questions.question: screen time concerns
answers: Set age-appropriate limits and create device-free routines (meals, bedtime). Model healthy screen habits as a family.
Encourage active play, outdoor time, and hobbies to replace mindless scrolling.
If screen use affects mood, sleep, or school, consider a gradual reduction plan and talk to a professional if needed.

questions.question: my child gets angry easily
answers: Name the feeling and set clear, calm limits. Teach coping skills like breathing, counting, or a quiet corner routine.
Track triggers (hunger, fatigue, transitions) and use predictable schedules. Praise calm attempts.
If aggression is frequent or unsafe, seek guidance from a child psychologist or pediatrician.

questions.question: worried about self-harm or safety
answers: Take any mention of self-harm seriously. Stay with your child, listen without judgment, and remove unsafe items.
Contact a local crisis line or mental health professional right away for guidance specific to your area.
If your child is in immediate danger, please seek emergency services immediately.

questions.question: what is science
answers: Science is a way of understanding the world by asking questions, observing, and testing ideas through experiments.
It uses evidence to discover how things work—from tiny atoms to stars in space—and helps us make better decisions.

questions.question: what are the states of matter
answers: Common states of matter are solid, liquid, gas, and plasma. Solids keep shape, liquids take container shape, gases spread out, and plasma is ionized gas found in stars.
Heating or cooling can change states—for example, ice (solid) melts to water (liquid) and boils to steam (gas).

questions.question: what is photosynthesis
answers: Photosynthesis is the process by which plants use sunlight, carbon dioxide, and water to make glucose and oxygen. It occurs mainly in leaves using chlorophyll.
Basic equation: carbon dioxide + water + light energy -> glucose + oxygen.

questions.question: what is gravity
answers: Gravity is the force of attraction between masses. It pulls objects toward each other, like keeping us on Earth.
The more massive and the closer objects are, the stronger the gravitational pull.

questions.question: how do electric circuits work
answers: An electric circuit is a closed path that lets current flow from a power source through components and back. Voltage pushes charges; resistance opposes flow.
In series circuits current is the same through all components; in parallel, voltage is the same across branches.

questions.question: what is the water cycle
answers: The water cycle moves water through evaporation, condensation, precipitation, and collection. Sunlight drives evaporation; clouds form by condensation; rain or snow falls as precipitation.
This cycle cleans and redistributes Earth’s water constantly.

questions.question: tell me about the solar system
answers: Our solar system has the Sun, eight planets, dwarf planets, moons, asteroids, and comets. Planets in order: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune.
The Sun is a star that provides light and energy, holding the system together with gravity.

questions.question: what is an ecosystem
answers: An ecosystem is a community of living things interacting with nonliving things like air, water, and soil.
Energy flows from producers (plants) to consumers (animals) to decomposers, forming food chains and food webs.

questions.question: what are atoms and molecules
answers: Atoms are the basic building blocks of matter, made of protons, neutrons, and electrons. Molecules form when two or more atoms bond together.
Examples: O2 is an oxygen molecule, H2O is a water molecule made of hydrogen and oxygen atoms.

questions.question: explain forces and motion
answers: A force is a push or pull that can change an object’s motion. Balanced forces cancel; unbalanced forces cause acceleration.
Newton’s laws describe inertia, F=ma, and action-reaction pairs.

questions.question: what is magnetism
answers: Magnetism is a force from moving electric charges. Magnets have north and south poles; like poles repel and unlike poles attract.
Electromagnets are made by running current through coils—useful in motors and speakers.

questions.question: what is the scientific method
answers: Typical steps: ask a question, research, form a hypothesis, test with an experiment, analyze data, draw conclusions, and share results.
Good experiments change only one variable at a time and use controls when possible.

questions.question: basics of the human body
answers: Body systems include circulatory, respiratory, digestive, nervous, and more. The heart pumps blood, lungs exchange oxygen and carbon dioxide, and the stomach/intestines digest food.
Systems work together to keep the body in balance (homeostasis).
